liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: We have an update on the UN Security Council's emergency meeting. It has taken no immediate action on a demand from the United States that all 15 members strongly condemn "these heinous terrorist attacks committed by Hamas". US deputy ambassador Robert Wood said after the meeting that "a good number of countries", but not all, denounced the unprecedented incursion by Hamas into Israel on Saturday morning. Russia's UN ambassador, Vassily Nebenzia, told The Associated Press that the US was trying to say at the meeting that Russia isn't condemning the attacks, but "that’s untrue". "It was in my comments," Mr Nebenzia said. "We condemn all the attacks on civilians." He said Russia's message was: "It's important to stop the fighting immediately, to go to a cease-fire, and to meaningful negotiations which were stalled for decades." China’s UN ambassador, Zhang Jun, expressed a similar position as he headed into the meeting. But Mr Wood said the international community must strongly condemn "this unprovoked invasion and the terrorist attacks" until Hamas ends its "violent terrorist activity against the Israeli people". AP
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: UN takes no immediate action after emergency meeting

children.content: We have an update on the
on a demand from the United States that all 15 members strongly condemn "these heinous terrorist attacks committed by Hamas".
US deputy ambassador Robert Wood said after the meeting that "a good number of countries", but not all, denounced the unprecedented incursion by Hamas into Israel on Saturday morning.
Russia's UN ambassador, Vassily Nebenzia, told The Associated Press that the US was trying to say at the meeting that Russia isn't condemning the attacks, but "that’s untrue".
"It was in my comments," Mr Nebenzia said. "We condemn all the attacks on civilians."
He said Russia's message was: "It's important to stop the fighting immediately, to go to a cease-fire, and to meaningful negotiations which were stalled for decades."
China’s UN ambassador, Zhang Jun, expressed a similar position as he headed into the meeting.
But Mr Wood said the international community must strongly condemn "this unprovoked invasion and the terrorist attacks" until Hamas ends its "violent terrorist activity against the Israeli people".

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: We heard earlier that the US doesn't have any evidence Iran was involved in the Hamas attack, but that is their concern. Reuters has just dropped an update from Tehran. Iranian President Ebrahim Raisi said during a cabinet meeting the attack on Israel was "a manifestation of resistance and standing against the fake Zionist regime". "The Palestinian people, the Palestinian soldiers, all Palestinian groups, and the Islamic Ummah really should be congratulated for this victory." President Raisi has referred to "Palestinian people", but it's important to note the difference between the soldiers of Hamas and the civilian population. The attack on Israel was a Hamas operation.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Iran weighs in

children.content: We heard earlier that the US doesn't have any evidence Iran was involved in the Hamas attack, but that is their concern.
Reuters has just dropped an update from Tehran.
Iranian President Ebrahim Raisi said during a cabinet meeting the attack on Israel was "a manifestation of resistance and standing against the fake Zionist regime".
"The Palestinian people, the Palestinian soldiers, all Palestinian groups, and the Islamic Ummah really should be congratulated for this victory."
President Raisi has referred to "Palestinian people", but it's important to note the difference between the soldiers of Hamas and the civilian population. The attack on Israel was a Hamas operation.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Reporting by Ashleigh Barraclough Australian man Daniel Moritz was at the music festival near Gaza which came under attack by Hamas militants. So far, 260 bodies have been recovered. Mr Moritz said he and some friends were enjoying the festival when they were caught off guard. "Around 6am, we noticed bombings above our head — no sirens, nothing went off," he told ABC Radio Melbourne. "Totally surprised, totally unaware and unprotected." He and his five friends decided to flee in their car straight away. "We just came to the decision, our friends, to get out of there, leave our stuff, leave our tents — everything," he said. "Luckily, we parked really close to the entrance. We found a hole in the fence so we managed to get out faster. "We started to head north, we thought we were protected, and suddenly a machine gun started going off, just shooting at us full force. "We hear the whistles of the bullets flying over our heads, we're ducking down in the car." He said he and his friends managed to escape uninjured, and he's now back home in northern Israel. "What's going on right now in the country is chaos," he said.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: 'Bullets flying over our head': Australian man describes attack at music festival near Gaza

children.content: Daniel Moritz, left, was at the music festival when it came under attack.

He and his five friends decided to flee in their car straight away.

"Luckily, we parked really close to the entrance. We found a hole in the fence so we managed to get out faster.
"We started to head north, we thought we were protected, and suddenly a machine gun started going off, just shooting at us full force.
"We hear the whistles of the bullets flying over our heads, we're ducking down in the car."
He said he and his friends managed to escape uninjured, and he's now back home in northern Israel.
"What's going on right now in the country is chaos," he said.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: If you've been paying attention to the news in recent months (and why wouldn't you be, you're on a business and markets blog after all) you'll be familiar with the story of climate protesters targeting the home of Woodside CEO Meg O'Neill. The climate protesters were widely condemned for targeting Ms O'Neill's private home in August, which was was filmed by Four Corners for an upcoming story, and has been the subject of dozens of headlines since the incident happened. Now, the full story from the Four Corners team has been published — and you can read the inside story of what happened when climate protesters targeted the Woodside boss from reporte rs Hagar Cohen, Mayeta Clark and Dylan Welch below:
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: What happened when climate protesters targeted the private home of Woodside's CEO

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: The ASX has opened higher at the beginning of trade on Monday morning, up 0.4% to 6,982 points as of 10:35am AEDT. (If you want more up-to-date figures, jump to the top of the blog and expand the pinned post for live market updates for the major ASX indices.) Energy stocks are mostly responsible for the higher opening, with the sector up 2.1%. The basic materials sector is also up 1.3%, while academic and educational services picked up 0.9%. Utilities (+0.5%), consumer cyclicals (+0.4%) and real estate (+0.2%) round out the early gains for the sectors. Consumer non-cyclicals have had the biggest drop so far (-0.6%), followed by industrials (-0.1%). The technology, healthcare and financials sectors are all flat. The best performers so far: De Grey Mining +8.5% Bellevue Gold +6.9% Evolution Mining +5.7% Capricorn Metals +5.5% Northern Star Resources +5.4% And the worst performers so far: Weebit Nano -10.9% Magellan Financial -2.7% Qantas -1.7% Paladin Energy -1.5% Life360 -1.3%
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Boost in energy stocks sends ASX higher at beginning of trade

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Parent company of IGA, Metcash, says the CEO of its liquor branch, Chris Baddock, has retired from the role for health reasons. In a short statement uploaded to the ASX earlier this morning, Metcash says John Barakat will take over the role in the interim while the company searches for a successor. Metcash CEO Doug Jones thanked Mr Baddock for his "significant contribution" in growing the company's liquor pillar, and said he would take up a part-time advisory role with Metcash after a four-month break to assist with the growth of the liquor division.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Metcash Liquor CEO retires from role for health reasons

children.content: Parent company of IGA, Metcash, says the CEO of its liquor branch, Chris Baddock, has retired from the role for health reasons.
In a short statement uploaded to the ASX earlier this morning, Metcash says John Barakat will take over the role in the interim while the company searches for a successor.

Metcash CEO Doug Jones thanked Mr Baddock for his "significant contribution" in growing the company's liquor pillar, and said he would take up a part-time advisory role with Metcash after a four-month break to assist with the growth of the liquor division.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: The Crows have opted not to match the contract offered to Tom Doedee by Brisbane. They have received end of first round compensation (currently pick 19) from the AFL. That will get bumped back as other compo picks come in, and even further on draft night. But still, that's an incredible result for the Crows. Everyone shakes hands and goes home happy with that one.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Adelaide to receive first round pick for Tom Doedee

children.content: The Crows have opted not to match the contract offered to Tom Doedee by Brisbane.
They have received end of first round compensation (currently pick 19) from the AFL. That will get bumped back as other compo picks come in, and even further on draft night.
But still, that's an incredible result for the Crows. Everyone shakes hands and goes home happy with that one.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: As a restricted free agent, the Crows have the option to match the contract offered by the Lions to Doedee and thereby force a trade. But Adelaide almost certainly won't do that. Tom Doedee is nearly a Lion.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: The Lions have lodged their bid for Tom Doedee

children.content: As a restricted free agent, the Crows have the option to match the contract offered by the Lions to Doedee and thereby force a trade.
But Adelaide almost certainly won't do that. Tom Doedee is nearly a Lion.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Sydney will be one of the busiest clubs over the next two weeks as they look to put the finishing touches on a squad they believe can compete for a flag. As mentioned before, James Jordon and Joel Hamling have already joined as free agents, so there has been no cost to the Swans there. But both Brodie Grundy and Taylor Adams are keen to head to the harbour city too, and those deals will need to be done via trades. The Swans currently have picks 11, 23, 31, 44 and 52. They will not want to use pick 11 in either of these deals, but both Melbourne and Collingwood will be eyeing off that pick 23. So is it 23 for Adams and 31 for Grundy? Vice versa? Or will some of those later picks needed be in to flesh things out? No doubt the Swans will get their men, but there could be some negotiating to get through first.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Taylor Adams, Brodie Grundy and the Swans' dilemma

As mentioned before, James Jordon and Joel Hamling have already joined as free agents, so there has been no cost to the Swans there. But both Brodie Grundy and Taylor Adams are keen to head to the harbour city too, and those deals will need to be done via trades.
11, 23, 31, 44 and 52. They will not want to use pick 11 in either of these deals, but both Melbourne and Collingwood will be eyeing off that pick 23.

So is it 23 for Adams and 31 for Grundy? Vice versa? Or will some of those later picks needed be in to flesh things out? No doubt the Swans will get their men, but there could be some negotiating to get through first.
